sub_topic: Calculation of enthalpy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
What is the enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions, given the balanced chemical equation below:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

(Hint: Use the standard enthalpies of formation of CH4, O2, CO2, and H2O to calculate the enthalpy change for the reaction)
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas, we need to use the standard enthalpies of formation for each compound involved in the reaction. The standard enthalpy of formation (ΔHf°) is the change in enthalpy when one mole of a substance is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states.

The standard enthalpies of formation for the compounds involved in the reaction are as follows:

ΔHf° (CH4) = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (O2) = 0 kJ/mol (since O2 is an element in its standard state)
ΔHf° (CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf° (H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol

The enthalpy change for the reaction (ΔHr°) can be calculated using the following formula:

ΔHr° = Σ [ΔHf° (products)] - Σ [ΔHf° (reactants)]

For the given reaction:

ΔHr° = [1 × ΔHf° (CO2) + 2 × ΔHf° (H2O)] - [1 × ΔHf° (CH4) + 2 × ΔHf° (O2)]

ΔHr° = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × (0 kJ/mol)]

ΔHr° = (-393.5 - 571.6 + 74.8) kJ/mol

ΔHr° = -890.3 kJ/mol

The enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions is -890.3 kJ/mol.
